item.title: Earnings Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

The Earnings Tax is a tax on salaries, wages, commissions and other compensation paid to an employee who is employed or renders services to an employer. If you are a resident of Philadelphia or a non-resident who works in Philadelphia, and your employer is not required to withhold the tax, you must register for an Earnings Tax Account. You can register for an Earnings account on our website using your Social Security Number.

Who Must File

The Earnings Tax must be filed and paid by Philadelphia residents or non-residents who work in Philadelphia who do not have the City Wage Tax withheld from their paycheck. The most common situation that requires the filing and payment of the Earnings Tax is those who work for out of state employers. They are not required to withhold Philadelphia’s wage tax. Earning Tax is taxed at the same rates as the wage tax for residents and non-residents.

When to File

The Earnings Tax must be filed and paid quarterly along with an annual reconciliation at the end of each calendar year.

Exclusions from Earnings Tax

  • Those who have City Wage Tax withheld from their paycheck
  • Individuals and partners that file and pay the Net Profits Tax

Rates

  • 3.92% (Resident)
  • 3.4915% (Non-Resident)

Tax Type Code

02

No Reciprocal Agreements

The City of Philadelphia is not a party to any reciprocal tax agreements with any other municipality. Non-residents of Pennsylvania cannot claim a tax credit against Philadelphia Earnings Tax for income taxes paid to any other state or political subdivision. Residents of Philadelphia employed outside of Pennsylvania may be required to file and pay a local income tax in that jurisdiction in addition to Philadelphia Earnings Tax.

item.title: Information needed before you file your taxes online
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Federal Entity Identification Number (EIN) or you Social Security Number (SSN) or Philadelphia Tax Account number; AND
Philadelphia Department of Revenue PIN (personal identification number).

item.title: Pin Number for a business registered online
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Your PIN is generated by the City when you register your business online. If you have never used our online system Apply for a PIN If you have received a PIN in the past Login Forgot Pin

item.title: Difficulty Using the e-pay Site
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: For trouble with your PIN, accessing the online site, making credit card, debit card, or e-check payments: Call: 215-683-2435 For general account questions: Call: 215-686-6600 For Returns on a Disk (ROAD) Software questions: Call: 215-686-6582 or 6459.

item.title: Business Taxes you have to pay in the City of Philadelphia
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Corporations Taxes Business Income and Receipts Tax Wage Taxes Business Use and Occupancy Taxes   Individuals and partnerships Business Income and Receipts Net Profit taxes Wage Taxes Business Use and Occupancy Taxes

item.title: Registering your Commercial or Residential Alarm
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Register your residential or commercial burglary or robbery alarm system with the Philadelphia Police Department. You need to register all new and existing alarms that are being transfer to a new owner, occupant or user within 5 days. You are allowed 2 false alarms a year.

Mail Payments & Form To:

Department Of Finance Code Unit P.O. Box 56318 Philadelphia, Pa 19130-6318

Fee:

Annual Alarm Registration Fee Is $50 Send a check or money order made payable to: City of Philadelphia

Supporting Links:

Alarm System Registration Online Form

item.title: Food Safety Certification
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Stationary food businesses must have an employee certified in food safety present at all times. These designated employees must complete a food safety course that is approved by the Philadelphia Department of Public Health and must obtain an official City of Philadelphia Food Safety Certificate.
The Certificate must be posted at the food business where customers can view it.
Certificates are valid for five years, after which the employee must complete and pass another food safety course approved by the Philadelphia Department of Public Health.
NOTE: Businesses selling only pre‐packaged, non‐hazardous foods are exempt from this requirement.
FEES: Application Fee - $30

item.title: City Wage Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The City Wage Tax is a tax on salaries, wages, commissions and other compensation paid to an employee who is employed by or renders services to an employer. All Philadelphia residents owe the City Wage Tax regardless of where they work. Non-residents who work in Philadelphia must also pay the Wage Tax.

Filing Frequency Determination

The filing frequency is determined by the amount of wage tax withheld by the employer according to the following schedule:
  • Quarterly: Less than $350 Philadelphia per month.
  • Monthly: Greater than $350 but less than $16,000 per month.
  • Semi-Monthly: For an employer with bi-weekly payroll who withholds Philadelphia wage taxes of $16,000 or more per month.
  • Weekly: Greater than $16,000 or more per month.
Semi-Monthly and Weekly wage tax payers must remit their wage tax payments electronically through the Automated Clearing House (ACH). Learn more under Payments & E-File.

RATES:

3.92% (Resident) 3.4915% (Non-Resident)

Non-Taxable Income for Wage Tax

  • A scholarship or stipend as part of a degree program AND you do not provide a service
  • Pension payments
  • Workmen's compensation
  • Active military service pay and bonuses
  • Death benefits
  • Employer paid insurance premiums
  • Witness and juror fees
Tax Type Code 01

item.title: School Income Taxes (SIT)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The School Income Tax (SIT) is filed annually. The School District of Philadelphia imposes a tax on different classes of net income. Examples of taxable income are dividends, certain interest, certain rents, and royalties. All residents of Philadelphia who receive these types of income must pay the tax.

Rate

3.924% on unearned income

Tax Type Code

29

Taxable Income for SIT

  • Dividends
  • Interest Income
  • S Corp Income
  • Partnerships Distributions
  • Estates and Trusts Income
  • Short Term Capital Gains (held 6 months or less)
  • Rental Income
  • Other Taxable Income

Exempt Income for School Income Tax

  • Dividends
  • Interest
  • Other Income

item.title: Business Privilege Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
(formerly known as Business Income & Receipts Tax (BIRT)) Based on both gross receipts and net income. Both parts must be ﬁled. The BIRT is filed and paid annually for business activity from the prior year. With each filing an estimate for the following year's BIRT must be paid in full.

Who Must File

Every individual, partnership, association and corporation engaged in a business, profession or other activity for proﬁt within the City of Philadelphia must ﬁle a Business Income & Receipts Tax Return, whether or not they earned a proﬁt during the preceding year. Persons engaged in real estate rental activity, residential included, are usually considered to be in business.

Rate

1.415 mills on gross receipts; and 6.45% on taxable net income

Tax Type Code

24

item.title: Tobacco Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Products subject to this tax are ones that contain tobacco for smoking or other consumption and tobacco related products, including rolling papers, cigars, smokeless tobacco, pipe tobacco or other loose tobacco. Businesses must collect the tax and remit it to the city. The Tobacco Tax is paid and filed annually by January 31st of each year for the prior year's sales. This tax must be filed online.

Exclusions from this tax:

Cigarettes Little Cigars

Rate

$0.036 for individually rolled items, like cigars $0.36 per pack of rolling papers $0.36 per ounce of all other tobacco and tobacco-related items

item.title: Net Profit Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Every individual residing in Philadelphia during 2014 and operating a business or other activity within or outside of Philadelphia and non-residents of Philadelphia, if engaged in such activities within Philadelphia, are subject to the Net Profits Tax.
Corporations are not subject to the Net Profits Tax.
Every partnership, limited partnership, limited liability company filing with the IRS as a partnership, association, or other group of two or more persons operating a business within Philadelphia, whether residents or non-residents of Philadelphia, is subject to the Net Profits Tax. A partnership comprised solely of corporate partners must file a Net Profits Tax return even if no tax liability exists. The City of Philadelphia follows the Federal tax treatment for LLCs. If the LLC chose corporate tax treatment, it would not be liable for Net Profits Tax. If the LLC chose to be treated as a partnership or as a disregarded entity, treated for federal filing purposes as an individual, it would be liable for Net Profits Tax.
The 2014 Business Income and Receipts and Net Profits taxes are due by April 15, 2015. A return must be filed even if an overall loss is incurred. Failure to file a return by the due date could result in the imposition of fines, legal costs and non-filer penalties. Payment of tax must be made using the preprinted coupons and postage paid envelope provided to existing taxpayers.
Do not enclose payments with your tax return.

item.title: Business Terminated - Change Form
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: If your business terminated, changed organization or entity, complete a Change Form. If you maintain a Commercial Activity license but did not actively engage in business during 2014, complete a Change Form to indicate that you are not in business. Do not file the 2014 Business Income and Receipts and/or Net Profits tax returns. If you begin a business again with the same Federal Identification or Social Security number you should reinstate your Philadelphia tax account number. In this scenario, you will not have to pay for an additional commercial activity license. If there was a change of business entity (e.g., individual proprietorship to corporation), you need a new Philadelphia Tax Account Number and commercial activity license ($300 lifetime or $50 annual fee). Register online for a tax account number in the "Business Taxes" section. A single Change Form can be used for all tax types.

item.title: Use & Occupancy Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Use and Occupancy Tax is a tax on the business, trade or other commercial use and occupancy of real estate located in Philadelphia.

WHO MUST FILE

  1. Every owner of real estate used or occupied for business purposes.
  2. Every landlord or other person authorized to collect rents for real estate used or occupied for business purposes. The landlord or other persons authorized to collect rentals is required to collect the tax due and remit it to the City along with any portion of the tax for which the landlord or other person is liable.
  3. The failure of any person to receive a tax return does not excuse them from the responsibility of filing a return and paying the tax due.
  4. All returns must be signed by the preparer.
The tax is due if:
  • Your business is physically located in Philadelphia.
  • You operate your business from your Philadelphia residence.
  • Tenants, sub-tenants or owners use the Philadelphia property for business purposes.

Rate

1.13% with a $2,000 annual exemption

item.title: Real Estate Taxes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Real Estate Tax bills are sent in December for the following year and payments are due March 31st. If you pay after March 31, you are subject to increased charges which are collectively called "additions". At year-end these charges are capitalized and become tax principal on which interest and penalty will accrue. Get a discount of 1% by paying before the last day of February. If you have a mortgage, your tax bill may be sent directly to your mortgage company for payment from your escrow fund.

Rate

.6018% (City) +.7382% (School) = 1.34% (Total)

Tax Type Code

60

item.title: Commercial / Multi-unit Trash Collection
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Solid Resources Fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) will be imposed annually on any commercial establishment or multi-unit property receiving city collection of rubbish and recycling materials. Eligibility for the City's commercial collection services and the fee will remain as follows:
  • Any private premises eligible under Section Seven of Regulations Governing Municipal Collection of Refuse shall be eligible for this service fee
  • Premises must have equal to or less than 6 units, and not exceed the set out limits.
  • Weekly set out limit for non-recyclable rubbish can not exceed six 32-gallon receptacles or twelve plastic bags, or an equivalent combination of the two. There is no limit on recyclables
  • Vacant premises are not eligible for city collection or the service fee
Multi-unit premises occupied by the owner, and not rented will be exempt from the fee

item.title: Block Party and Events
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
NO APPLICATIONS WILL BE PROCESSED WITHIN FOUR (4) WORKING DAYS OF THE EVENT. Applicant must be a resident of the block being closed. Applications for block parties must have a petition signed by 75% of the households on the block Non-block party events must have a petition signed by 90% of the households on the block. If the event is being held on a street that doesn’t have any residents, a copy of an insurance certificate to cover the cost of any damages from the event must be submitted with this application. One application may contain multiple event dates. Street events will only be approved for (5) dates a year, per block. One check or money order for all dates is acceptable. Rain dates should occur within one (1) week of the original event date. No rain dates will be permitted on holidays. If the street being closed for an event is the only entrance/exit to another street (a "T" street), a petition to close that "T" street is also required.

For events planned on main streets in business corridors,

contact the Managing Director's Office 215-686-3488.

Approved Block Parties Days & Hours

  • Memorial Day
  • Independence Day
  • Labor Day
  • Weekends 8 am to 8:30 pm

Approved Other Events Hours

Birthday Celebrations, Weddings, Proms, Serenades & other non-block party events
  • Max of 6 hours

Special Trash Removal

Residents will assume responsibility for the proper disposal of all trash and recyclables associated with the event. For trash pickup on unscheduled day (contact 215-686-5502 to arrange 5 days prior to event) $50.00

item.title: Street Closure Permits Fees
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
CLOSURE TYPE  RATE FOR CC/UC RATE ALL OTHER MAX DURATION
Sidewalk Shelter platform with 6 Foot Wide Pedestrian Walkway no fee no fee 1 year
Partial Sidewalk Closure $1.00 per foot per week* $.75 per foot per week* 1 year

item.title: Street Closure Permits
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
All applications for a street closure permit must be received by mail or fax by 12 noon at least 10 business days in advance of the start date. The unit reviews closure areas and determines fees based on schedule and approvals.
A payment invoice will be faxed or emailed to the applicant.
Methods of payment include in person cash, check, money order and Epay.
Once payment is received the permit will be faxed or emailed to the applicant.

item.title: Property Owner Becoming a Water Customer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Property Owners

If you are a new property owner, you should take the following steps to receive water service:
  • If your deed is recorded, your account will be updated and you will begin to receive bills in your name.
  • If your deed is not recorded and it is essential that you receive the bill in your name, present your settlement sheet to the Water Revenue Bureau.
  • If there is no meter on the property, a meter must be installed within 30 days after the settlement date.
  • Property owners who rent out their property need to meet specific licensing and permitting as required by the Department of Licenses & Inspections

item.title: Tenant Becoming a Water Customer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Tenants

If you are a tenant, you may apply for water service in your name by bringing the following documents to a Customer Service location:
  • Consent from the owner for you to have service in your name.
  • A viable street address for the owner. PO Boxes are not accepted.
  • Two (2) official pieces of personal identification, one is a current government issue with photo
  • Proof of residency, such as a lease, rent book or canceled check
  • Current utility bills in your name listing the street address for the property.
  • A water meter reading. If there is no meter on the property, a meter must be installed before the application is approved.

item.title: Occupant Becoming a Water Customer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Occupants

If you are an occupant (a potential owner of the property or a person who has permission to live in the property without a lease), you may take the following steps to receive water service:
  • Two (2) official pieces of personal identification, one is a current government issue with photo
  • Complete an application at a Customer Service location near you
  • Obtain a current reading of your meter
  • Present evidence of occupancy or potential ownership. Evidence includes:
    • Death Certificate of Owner
    • Current utility bills in your name and for this property
    • Lease Purchase Agreements
    • Letter of Authorization to occupy property
    • Other legal documentation If there is no meter on the property, a meter must be installed before the application is approved.

item.title: Commercial Property Owner Becoming A Water Customer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Commercial Property Owners

  • Visit the Department of Licenses & Inspections for specific permitting and licensing requirements
  • For assistance with the stormwater portion of your water bill, please visit the Philadelphia Water Department for information on their Stormwater Assistance Program (SWAP)

item.title: Water Shutoff Notice
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If shut-off is for non-payment and imminent, you must call us or come into any of our three customer service locations and see a representative to make payment arrangements to stop the shut-off.

Center City - Water Revenue

Municipal Services Building - Public Services Concourse 1401 John F. Kennedy Boulevard (215) 686-6880 Hours 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.

North Philadelphia - Tax & Water Revenue

Hope Plaza 22nd & Somerset St. Hours 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.

Northeast Philadelphia - Tax & Water Revenue

Rear of Northeast Shopping Mall 9239 Roosevelt Blvd. Hours 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.

item.title: Reason why your water is shutoff
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Your water and sewer service may be shut off if:
  • Nonpayment - You do not pay your water and sewer bill on time. Before your service is shut off, the Water Revenue Bureau (WRB) will send you one or more of the following notices:
    • Bill Message - A message will be on your bill when your payment is late. When you receive this message, you can either pay the entire amount due or schedule payment arrangements.
    • Shut Off Notice 1 - This is the second notice that will be sent to you. It warns you that your water and sewer services may be shut off if you do not pay your bill.
    • Shut Off Notice 2 - This is the final notice that will be sent to you. It warns you that your water and sewer services will be shut off if payment is not received by the specified date.
  • Non-compliance - You have denied access to the Philadelphia Water Department (PWD) for reading or repairing your meter
  • Public Safety - Emergencies or health and safety violations have occurred
  • Fraud - A customer application is found to be based on a false identity or false information

item.title: Restoring your Water Service
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Whenever possible, the Water Department will turn your water and sewer service back on within 24 hours after you have made satisfactory payment or payment plan. This only applies when service is shut off for non-payment. You must call us or come into one of our three customer service locations when making a payment to restore water service.

Center City - Water Revenue

Municipal Services Building - Public Services Concourse 1401 John F. Kennedy Boulevard (215) 686-6880 Hours 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.

North Philadelphia - Tax & Water Revenue

Hope Plaza 22nd & Somerset St. Hours 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.

Northeast Philadelphia - Tax & Water Revenue

Rear of Northeast Shopping Mall 9239 Roosevelt Blvd. Hours 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.

item.title: Discontinuance of Service for Vacant Property
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When you no longer need water and sewer services, you must:
  • Obtain a Discontinuance Permit (D-permit) from the Department of Licenses and Inspections
  • Pay the fee for the Discontinuance Permit. A Discontinuance Permit stops billing of your service charge and usage charge at your property from the date of the permit. You will still be assessed a Stormwater Charge.
  • Once PWD receives the information from L & I, they will come out and remove the water service and remove the meter.
  • The issuance of a D-permit is not a temporary solution for shutting off your water and avoiding service charges. If water service is needed after the discontinuance, a new permit must be obtained, as well as hiring a certified plumber to facilitate the process. This could ultimately result in thousands of dollars of additional expenses incurred by the homeowner.

item.title: Water Bill Dispute
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Water Customer Service:

(215) 686-6880 wrb.helpdesk@phila.gov Monday - Friday 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. If you think your bill is in error please contact customer service ﬁrst. There may be an easy resolution. Contact us if you disagree with your water bill. If you are still in disagreement about your bill after speaking with a customer service representative, read the following to find out which appeal process you must follow.

Water Revenue Bureau Informal Hearings

You can request an informal hearing from WRB for the following reasons:
  • Dispute whether your water bill payment agreement terms have been properly applied
  • Dispute rejection or revocation of acceptance of an application including Water Revenue Assistance Program (WRAP) applications
  • Dispute water shut off for nonpayment or lack of access to the meter to change, repair or read
Please call us to obtain an informal hearing request form. After your Informal Hearing, if you disagree with the outcome, or if you choose not to have an Informal Hearing, you may send a petition for hearing to the Tax Review Board.

item.title: Water/Sewer Emergencies
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Contact:

Report dangerous conditions such as leaks and damaged pipes (215) 685-6300 24 hours, 7 days

item.title: Problems with your Water Meter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Contact:

(215) 685-6300 24 hours, 7 days

item.title: Earning Tax Rates for Philadelphia Resident
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Earning Tax Rates for Non-Philadelphia Resident
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Realty Transfer Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Realty Transfer Tax is levied on the sale or transfer of Real Estate located in Philadelphia. The City tax rate is applied to the sale price, plus any assumed debt, or if no sales price exists, then the tax is calculated using a formula that is based on the assessed value as set by the Office of Property Assessment which results in a computed fair market value. Underpayment of the tax due to falsifying the terms of a real estate transaction or failing to record a real estate transaction may result in penalties of up to 50% of the tax due.

Rate:

4% Total 3% goes to City 1% goes to Commonwealth

Exclusions from Realty Transfer Tax

The transfer of real estate between family members is exempt. All family exemptions require documentation.

Examples

between husband and wife, children of the same parent, lineal ascendants / descendants Fraudulent exemption claims will result in a bill for the full amount due including interest and penalty. Property that is received under a will is also exempt BUT property purchases from an estate are taxed. When a property is willed to multiple parties and one party buys the property from the estate, tax is due as it is not a transfer under the Will.

item.title: Amusement Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

This tax is imposed on the admission fee charged for attending any amusement in Philadelphia. Included are concerts, movies, athletic contests, night clubs and convention shows for which admission is charged. The Amusement Tax is filed and paid monthly for the prior month's activity. The Department of Revenue issues a "Monthly Amusement Tax Coupon Book" to simplify tax payment. Coupons can also be printed from Revenue's website.

Who Must File

The operator/provider of any amusement or the promoter of any show located in Philadelphia is responsible for collecting and remitting the tax. Holders of temporary amusement permits for one or more days are also responsible for collecting and remitting the tax. A report of tax collected must be ﬁled and the tax paid within ﬁve (5) days after the event is held.

Rate:

5%

item.title: Amusement Tax Exemptions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
• Religious Institutions
  • Educational (However, clubs or societies organized within a school for social or athletic purposes are not exempt.)
  • Charitable
  • Societies for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children or Animals
  • Societies or Organizations Conducted for the Sole Purpose of Maintaining Symphony Orchestras, Opera Performances and Artistic Presentations
  • Societies or Organizations Conducted and Maintained for the Purpose of Improving any Municipal Corporation
  • Societies or Organizations Conducted and Maintained for the Purpose of Maintaining a Cooperative or Community Center, Moving Picture Theatre, or Swimming Pool
  • Organizations or Persons in the Military or Naval Forces of the UnitedStates
  • Organizations or Societies Conducted and Maintained for the Purpose of Benefiting Members, Dependents of, or Heirs of Members of Police, or Paid or Volunteer Fire Departments
Application for Exemption

item.title: Parking Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

The Parking Tax is levied on the gross receipts from all financial transactions involving the parking or storing of automobiles or other motor vehicles in outdoor or indoor parking lots and garages in the City of Philadelphia. The Parking Tax rate is filed and paid monthly for the prior month's activity.

Rate:

20%

Who Must File

The Parking Tax is imposed on every person parking or storing a motor vehicle in or on a parking facility in Philadelphia. The person operating the parking facility is responsible for issuing the claim check, collecting the tax and paying it to the City.

Exclusions from the Parking Tax

Operated parking lots/garages for a building with residences who do not pay an additional fee for parking.

item.title: Hotel Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

Businesses operating as a Hotel must charge the Hotel Tax on the price of the room paid by the guest. This tax is imposed on the rental of a hotel room to accommodate paying guests. The Hotel Tax is filed and paid monthly for the prior month's activity. The Department of Revenue issues a "Monthly Hotel Tax Coupon Book" to simplify tax payment.

"Hotel"

Includes an apartment, hotel, motel, inn, guest house, bed and breakfast or other building located within the City which is available to rent for overnight lodging or use of facility space to persons seeking temporary accommodations.

Rate:

8.5%

Who Must File

The hotel operator must file and remit the tax. It is the hotel's responsibility to collect the tax from the guests paying for the room.

item.title: Liquor Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

The Liquor Tax is applied to the sale price of alcoholic beverages purchased at bars, restaurants, catered events, and at retail stores. Every sale of wine, liquor or malt and brewed beverages by any hotel, restaurant, club or other person holding a license or permit issued by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania to sell or dispense liquor, wine or malt and brewed beverages is subject to this tax. This includes catering that sells such beverages, as it is a portion of a total charge that includes beverages.

Rate:

10% on retail sales

Who Must File

  • Every hotel, restaurant, club or other person holding a license or permit issued by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania to sell or dispense liquor, wine or malt and brewed beverages
  • Catering companies or catering contracts that includes the sale or cover charge of such beverages

Exclusions

  • Sales from Pennsylvania Liquor Stores and Malt Beverage
  • Distributors Any retail sale of liquor or malt and brewed beverage that is subject to Pennsylvania's Sales and Use Tax

item.title: Mechanical Amusement Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

Any machine or device for amusement or entertainment which is operated by the insertion of a coin or token representing such coin, but excluding any machine or device which is operated by a sound production licensee.

Rate:

$100 per device per year

Who Must File

Every person who uses, or permits the use for profit, any mechanical amusement. Each mechanical amusement device shall be listed on the return with its serial number. When the return is received and the tax is paid, Revenue will issue a tax stamp to affix to the device for the year for which the tax has been paid.

item.title: Vehicle Rental Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

This is imposed as an excise tax on the rental of a Rental Vehicle in the City of Philadelphia. This occurs whenever a renter takes possession of a Rental Vehicle in the City of Philadelphia. Taxable transactions are rentals for a period of 29 or fewer consecutive days of a private passenger motor vehicle designed to transport 15 or fewer passengers or a truck, trailer or semi-trailer used in the transportation of property other than commercial freight where custody or possession is taken in Philadelphia.

Rate:

2%

Who Must File

Vehicle Rental Companies

Exclusions from the Parking Tax

  • Rentals for a period of 30 or more consecutive days.
  • Rentals of a fleet of 4 or less rental vehicles.

item.title: Outdoor Advertising Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

The Outdoor Advertising Tax is an excise tax on the purchase, rental or licensing of space on any building, parcel and sign support structure located within the City of Philadelphia for the purpose of installing, placing or maintaining an Outdoor Advertising Sign. The tax is applied to the purchase price paid to the Outdoor Advertising Sign Company by the renter or purchaser of the advertising space. The Outdoor Advertising Sign Company must collect the tax from the renter or purchaser of the space at the time the space is purchased or rented.

Rate:

7% on the purchase price

Who Must File

  • Outdoor Advertising Companies
  • Newsstands that advertise on the side of their structure

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Pay your Earnings Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Before you start

You do not have to manually pay your earnings tax if it already withheld from your paycheck.
  • You must have a Earnings Tax Account. Apply for one.
  • Have your Social Security Number or Individual Tax Identification Number handy. This is your Earnings Tax account number.

How long it takes

The process typically takes 30 minutes.

Fees:

Paying by Credit Card payment processing fee - 2.45% Paying by Debit Card payment processing fee - $5.95 Paying by e-Check - $0.35 Return Checks - $20.00

Other ways to pay

By mail

Complete this form and mail it to: Philadelphia Department of Revenue PO Box 1648 Philadelphia, PA 19105‐1648

Electronic funds transfer

You can setup electronic payments to be made directly from your bank account. Get started.

Supporting Links

Employee Earning Wage Tax Account Application 2014 Employee Earnings Tax Form due 4/15/15 2014 Employee Earnings Tax Instructions Non-Resident Earnings Allocation Worksheet

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: You need to file if you are a resident of Philadelphia and you are self employed or your employer does not deduct City wage taxes from your earnings or If you work in Philadelphia but do not live in Philadelphia and you are self employed or your employer does not deduct City wage taxes from your earnings

item.title: Pay your Alarm System Fine
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
All registered resident or commercial burglary or robbery alarm systems are allowed 2 false alarms a year. Any additional alarms are subjected to a $75 fine.

Other ways to pay

By mail

Send a check or money order Made payable to: City of Philadelphia Department of Finance Code Unit P.O. Box 56318 Philadelphia, Pa 19130-6318

FINES:

Alarm Non-Registration Fine - $150 - $300 False Alarm Fines - $75 Non-Payment False Alarm Penalties 1st notice $25 Non-Payment False Alarm Penalties 2nd notice $50

Disputes

Mail Disputes to:

Department of Finance Code Unit P.O. Box 56318 Philadelphia, Pa 19130-6318

Hearings on Disputes

Failure to answer or appeal shall be considered an admission of liability. Office of Administrative Review Land Title Building 100 S. Broad Street – 4th floor Philadelphia, PA

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The use of any unregistered resident or commercial burglary or robbery alarm system are subjected to a $150 - $300 fine per activation.

item.title: Pay your Sidewalk Fines
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Failure to pay or contest your code violation may result in the filing of a Code Enforcement Complaint in Municipal Court. The Court can impose up to a maximum fine of $300.00 plus Court costs. Each day a code violation continues, or is permitted to continue, shall constitute a separate offense for which a separate penalty may be imposed.

Fines:

Not Clearing Sidewalk 6 hrs after storm - $50 - $300 Sidewalks Littered - $000

By Mail

Send a check or money order made payable to: City of Philadelphia

Payments and form to:

City of Philadelphia Department of Finance P.O. Box 56318 Philadelphia, PA 19130-6318 DO NOT MAIL CASH. Write code violation notice number on check. Sign your name and address below.

In Person

Payments will be accepted at: Violations Branch, on behalf of the Finance Department 913 Filbert Street Philadelphia, PA 19107 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM Mon. thru Fri. 9:00 AM to 1:00 PM Sat. If payment is not received within 10 calendar days, you will be subject to additional penalties.

Telephone Inquiries

215-567-2605

Clean and Related Services Provided by other City Agencies

Abandoned Cars: Police Department 215-683-2277 Abandoned Houses: Department of Licenses & Inspections 215-686-2463 Littered Lots: Department of Licenses & Inspections 215-686-2463 Water/Sewer Inlet Cleaning: Water Department 215-685-6300

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Keeping Philadelphia litter-free will enhance the city's image and economic vitality. Compliance with the sanitation laws is also cost effective, should you receive a SWEEP fine, you can pay your SWEEP Code Violation Notice three ways.

item.title: Pay your Environmental Health Fees
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Fees:

Portable Toilet - $50 fee per location Storage/Holding Tank - $100 fee per location Septic Systems (new systems and repairs) $200 – Soil Probe $200 – Percolation Test $100 – Permit Processing Tobacco Retailer Permit $50. Tobacco Retailer Permit annual renewal fee $50. Tobacco Retailer Non-Permit fine $75 per day

Permits & Applications

Septic Systems (new systems and repairs) Call 215-685-7342 to request an application. Storage/Holding Tank - Permit Application Portable Toilet - Permit Application Tobacco Retailer Permit Application

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Our Environmental Health evaluates equipment, structures and systems to protect the environment and to improve public health.

item.title: Pay for your Food Safety Certification Applications
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Certificate must be posted at the food business where customers can view it. Certificates are valid for five years, after which the employee must complete and pass another food safety course approved by the Philadelphia Department of Public Health. NOTE: Businesses selling only pre‐packaged, non‐hazardous foods are exempt from this requirement.

Fees:

Application Fee - $30

BY Mail:

Philadelphia Department of Public Health Office of Food Protection 321 University Avenue, 2nd fl, Philadelphia, PA 19104 Send a check or money order made payable to: City of Philadelphia – EHS

Permits & Applications

Food Safety Application

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Stationary food businesses must have an employee certified in food safety present at all times. These designated employees must complete a food safety course that is approved by the Philadelphia Department of Public Health and must obtain an official City of Philadelphia Food Safety Certificate.

item.title: Pay your Parking Violations
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Fines:

Blocking Driveway - $51.00* Blocking Handicapped Ramp - $76.00 Blocking Mass Transit Vehicle - $101.00 Boot Fee - $150.00 Bus Zone - $51.00* Handicapped Space - $301.00 On Crosswalk - $51.00* Sidewalk - $51.00* Snow Route - $51.00 Taxi Stand - $31.00 Vehicle Towing and Impoundment Fee - $000.00 •Tickets for these violations in Center City or University City will be $25.00 higher.

SUPPORTING LINKS:

Table of Violations and Fines

Payments:

Send a check or money order made payable to: City of Philadelphia include the ticket number being paid. Do not mail cash.

Mail:

Parking Violations Branch  P.O. Box 41818 Philadelphia, PA 19101-1818

In person:

Parking Violations Branch  913 Filbert Street  Philadelphia, PA 19107 8:00 AM – 8:00 PM Weekdays  9:00 AM – 1:00 PM Saturday

By phone:

Call (888) 591-3636 to pay by Visa or Mastercard After the voice response system introduction, press “1″ 24/7.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Philadelphia Parking Authority employs three levels of enforcement of parking regulations: issuing parking tickets to vehicles that violate regulations; applying the boot to vehicles that accumulate unpaid tickets; and, in certain cases, towing and impounding vehicles until outstanding fines and fees are paid.

item.title: Pay your City Wage Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
All Philadelphia residents owe the City Wage Tax regardless of where they work. Non-residents who work in Philadelphia must also pay the Wage Tax.

FEES:

Paying by Credit Card payment processing fee - 2.45% Paying by Debit Card payment processing fee - $5.95 Paying by e-Check - $0.35 Return Checks - $20.00

By Mail:

Mail Annual Reconciliations:

City Of Philadelphia Department Of Revenue PO Box 1670 Philadelphia, PA 19105‐1670

Monthly. Semi­-Monthly & Quarterly Filers

Mail Payments with Coupons to Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue PO Box 8040 Philadelphia, PA 19105-8040

SUPPORTING LINKS:

2014 Tax Returns Specifications 2014 Wage Instructions 2014 Wage Tax Return Change Form W-2 Submission Instructions Wage Due Dates

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The City Wage Tax is a tax on salaries, wages, commissions and other compensation paid to an employee who is employed by or renders services to an employer.

item.title: Pay your School Income Taxes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Examples of taxable income are dividends, certain interest, certain rents, and royalties. All residents of Philadelphia who receive these types of income must pay the tax.

By Mail:

Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue PO Box 389 Philadelphia, PA 19105‐0389

FEES:

Paying by Credit Card payment processing fee - 2.45% Paying by Debit Card payment processing fee - $5.95 Paying by e-Check - $0.35 Return Checks - $20.00

SUPPORTING LINKS:

SIT Instructions SIT Returns

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The School Income Tax (SIT) is filed annually. The School District of Philadelphia imposes a tax on different classes of net income.

item.title: Pay your Business Privilege Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
(formerly known as Business Income & Receipts Tax (BIRT))

FEES:

Paying by Credit Card payment processing fee - 2.45% Paying by Debit Card payment processing fee - $5.95 Paying by e-Check - $0.35 Return Checks - $20.00

By Mail:

Mail Returns Requesting a Refund to

Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue P.O. Box 1137 Philadelphia, PA 19105-1137

Mail Returns Not Requesting a Refund to

Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue P.O. Box 1660 Philadelphia, PA 19105-1660

Mail All Payments With a Payment Coupon to

Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue PO Box 1393 Philadelphia, PA 19105-1393

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Based on both gross receipts and net income. Both parts must be ﬁled. The BIRT is filed and paid annually for business activity from the prior year. With each filing an estimate for the following year's BIRT must be paid in full.

item.title: Pay your Tobacco Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Tobacco Tax is paid and filed annually by January 31st of each year for the prior year's sales. This tax must be filed on-line.

FEES:

Paying by Credit Card payment processing fee - 2.45% Paying by Debit Card payment processing fee - $5.95 Paying by e-Check - $0.35 Return Checks - $20.00

By Mail:

Mail Payments with Coupons to

Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue PO Box 53250 Philadelphia, PA 19105

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Products subject to this tax are ones that contain tobacco for smoking or other consumption and tobacco related products, including rolling papers, cigars, smokeless tobacco, pipe tobacco or other loose tobacco. Businesses must collect the tax and remit it to the city.

item.title: Pay your Net Profits Tax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
After submitting the return online you must print the resulting confirmation page for your records. Payment of tax due for returns filed online should be made with the preprinted coupons mailed to you, by e-check or by credit card. A user fee is added when paying electronically.

FEES:

Paying by Credit Card payment processing fee - 2.45% Paying by Debit Card payment processing fee - $5.95 Paying by e-Check - $0.35 Return Checks - $20.00

By Mail:

Mail Returns Requesting a Refund to

Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue P.O. Box 1137 Philadelphia, PA 19105-1137

Mail Returns Not Requesting a Refund to

Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue P.O. Box 1660 Philadelphia, PA 19105-1660

Mail All Payments With a Payment Coupon to

Philadelphia Dept. of Revenue PO Box 1393 Philadelphia, PA 19105-1393

SUPPORTING LINKS:

Net Profit Tax Return Net Profit Tax Worksheets Net Profit Tax Instructions

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Net Profits Tax is filed annually and is levied on the net profits from the operation of a trade, business, profession, enterprise or other activity by: residents, even if business is conducted outside of Philadelphia and Non-residents who conduct business in Philadelphia.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Use and Occupancy Tax is a tax on the business, trade or other commercial use and occupancy of real estate located in Philadelphia.

item.title: Pay your Real Estate Taxes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you pay after March 31, you are subject to increased charges which are collectively called "additions". At year-end these charges are capitalized and become tax principal on which interest and penalty will accrue. Get a discount of 1% by paying before the last day of February. If you have a mortgage, your tax bill may be sent directly to your mortgage company for payment from your escrow fund.

FEES:

Paying by Credit Card payment processing fee - 2.45% or $1.95, whichever is greater Paying by Debit Card payment processing fee - $5.95 Paying by e-Check - $1.50 Return Checks - $20.00

SUPPORTING LINKS:

Department of Revenue P.O. Box 8409 Philadelphia, PA 19101-8409
